advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad uses actors, except for IMSAI's Finance Director Hersch Mandelman as the "Milk Man".</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTERS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIL'Z III</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice fish-eye picture of a Sil'z III illustrating a 1982 article about Technologic Revolution in the french mag TeleSoft.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #8</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert said : <br><br> <font color="#666666">The 8813 was built with you, the professional, in mind...<br><br> Using the 8813, one person can process what would normally require many secretaries, several bookkeepers and a great deal of time...<br><br> The 8813 slashes the professional's overhead. It's a powerful time and money-saving ally. Prices for complete system including printer start at less than $8,000.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, OCT. 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #3 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Victor tried to convince future IBM PC buyers that the Victor 9000 hardware technology was much more advanced than that of its competitor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 ADVERT & PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Price list</b><br><br> <b>VP-111 </b>Low cost microcomputer <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-114 </b>Expansion kit for VP-111 (3 KB RAM, I/O port and connectors) <b>$76</b><br> <b>VP-711 </b>Original VIP microcomputer <b>$199</b><br> <b>VP-44 </b>On board RAM expansion (4 x 2114 RAM chips) <b>$36</b><br> <b>VP-590 </b>Color board <b>$69</b><br> <b>VP-595 </b>Simple sound board (256 programmable frequencies) with speaker <b>$30</b><br> <b>VP-550 </b>Super sound board (Synthetiser with two sound channels <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-551 </b>Super sound 4 channels expansion <b>$74</b><br> <b>VP-570 </b>4 KB RAM memory expansion board <b>$95</b><br> <b>VP-580 </b>Two players keypad <b>$20</b><br> <b>VP-585 </b>Keypad interface board <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-560 </b>Eprom board for two 2716 EPROMS <b>$34</b><br> <b>VP-565 </b>2716 EPROM programmer with software <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-575 </b>Expansion board with 5 expansions sockets <b>$59</b><br> <b>VP-700 </b>4 KB Tiny Basic <b>$39</b><br> <b>VP-701 </b>Floating point Basic (cassette) <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-710 </b>Game listings <b>$10</b><br> <b>VP-720 </b>Game listings II <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-601 </b>Keyboard 128-character ASCII <b>$69</b> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LOGABAX STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>"What a quantum leap, Logabax!"<br> "I would say even more, what a quantum leap!"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://tintinomanie.chez.tiscali.fr/</b> © Moulinsart</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Prior to the 6800 computer, MSI manufactured 8" floppy disc units.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> THINKJET ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>August 1985</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each picture represents a customers target. Three of them are well known: Home/entertainement, office and educational uses. A fourth one is added for the first time, the senior citizens. Epson thought the QX-10 was user-friendly enough to be used by retired people. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 COLECO CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com/digitize/items/" target="_blank">Digitize, Textfiles.com</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #11</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRIDGE COMPUTER VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1982, the <b>Bridge Computer Company</b> (Newton, MASS) sold a Z80 software developper system with the InterSystems mainframe, CP/M 2.2 operating system and various optional programming languages.The configuration was:<br><br> - 6 Mhz. Z80-B CPU with memory management<br> - 256 KB RAM expandable to 1 MB<br> - Two 8" or 5.25" F.D. drives, single or double sided<br> - Optional 5" or 8" hard disk, up to 40 MB<br> - Televideo serial video terminal. <br><br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Does this sound too good to be true? Just fill your tank with the BRIDGE 3C formula for SPEED and shift into 'overdrive' with your bridge 3C Compiler System. Leave the other behind, let us provide you with the fuel for higher productivity...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - RECTO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert was for the Serie 5 and the ACS-8000 systems.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It will take your time, your body and your soul"...</blockquote>

computer.description:
These photos were sent by Pablo Alvarez Doval (Thank you!). This computer belongs to his uncle, unfortunately, he has no information about it. He says: "It's a huge computer, built in a metallic desk, with a printer, two 8" floppy drives, 12" green-screen monitor (I am not sure, but I do believe it is 12"), and a keyboard, everything you needed built in. It even had a chair to compliment it! Obviously, it is some kind of office computer".
It has indeed a 12" screen (white characters 25 x 80) en two 8" floppy drives 1,2 MB. A harddisk was optional. The programming language was Phocal. (Philips Office Computer Assembly Language).
The printer was a 9 pins dot matrix, 100 cps. The P330 was the last product of the Philips Office computers series. Then Philips came with the mircro computers and later the IBM compatibele PC's.
In 1992 the Philips computer line was ended.
_______
Contributors : Pablo Alvarez Doval, Roy Van Der Lee

item.description: ROM card #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ROM CARD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Two ROM cards are connected together, side by side.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Dani Galan</b> for all card pictures.</p></blockquote>
RAM card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> RAM CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>32 KB RAM card (16x4116 chips). Provision is made for a second 32 KB RAM bank. </blockquote>
CPU card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CPU CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the NEC 8080 processor at the upper right corner. I/O chips come also from NEC and Intel. </blockquote>
FDD card #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> FDD CARD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Like the ROM cards, two FDD cards are connected together.</blockquote>
FDD card #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> FDD CARD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The second FDD card uses its own 8080 microprocessor, also a NEC version.</blockquote>

computer.media: 2 x 8'' FDD, optional 7 MB 8'' hard diskPrograms loading was done by a minicassete software called PIOC (Program Input Output Cassette)
computer.name: P/330

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS P/430 KEYBOARD AND CONTROL PANEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>We are looking information about this machine.<br> Holger Groh is also looking for any technical information and documentation in order to bring his P/430 back to life.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Holger Groh</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 16-INCH HDD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Same capacity as a basic usb key but 10,000 times more heavy!<p class="petitgris">thanks to <b>Dani</b> for the picture</p></blockquote>
